content.content: Introduction to geometric patterns (matchstick patterns). Examples show square patterns and triangle patterns that continue indefinitely. For patterns we may wish to establish a rule or formula to determine how many matchsticks are needed for future figures.
Creating a summary table for matchstick patterns. Let figure number be n and number of matches be M.
Pattern table showing figure number, figure diagram, matches count, pattern formula, and explanation.
Using patterns to predict: the 10th figure has 10 x 3 + 1 = 31 matches, and the 100th figure has 100 x 3 + 1 = 301 matches.
Complete a table for the first four figures in the pattern (L-shaped figures). Find matches required for 10th and 50th figures. Write a description and predict a general rule for M in the nth figure.

content.content: Sam builds steel fences in sections. A 1-section fence uses 4 lengths of steel, a 2-section uses 7 lengths. Find how many lengths needed for a 63-section fence.
content.solution: When n is increased by 1, S is increased by 3. The S values are always 1 more than the 3n values. So S = 3n + 1. When n = 63, S = 190 lengths of steel are needed.

content.content: Introduction to number sequences using ball pattern. Let u_n represent the number of balls in the nth layer. The sequence 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, ... continues forever.
definitions: A number sequence is an ordered list of numbers defined by a rule.
The numbers in a sequence are called the terms of the sequence.

content.content: Three ways to describe a number sequence: (1) Using words - 'starting at 1, and increasing by 2 each time'. (2) Using an explicit formula - gives the nth term u_n in terms of n. The explicit formula for the ball pattern is u_n = 2n - 1. u_n is called the nth term or general term.
(3) Using a recursive formula - gives the nth term in terms of one or more preceding terms. The recursive formula for the ball pattern is u_1 = 1, u_n = u_{n-1} + 2 for n >= 2.
content.note: In a recursive formula, at least one initial term must be defined.

content.content: Definition of arithmetic sequence.
definitions: An arithmetic sequence is a sequence in which each term differs from the previous one by the same fixed number. We call this number the common difference.

content.content: Examples of arithmetic sequences.
examples: The sequence 1, 5, 9, 13, 17, .... is arithmetic with common difference 4
The sequence 42, 37, 32, 27, .... is arithmetic with common difference -5

content.content: The general term formula for arithmetic sequences.
content.note: The coefficient of d is one less than the term number.

content.content: The name 'arithmetic' is given because the middle term of any three consecutive terms is the arithmetic mean of the terms on either side.
Consider the sequence 3, 9, 15, 21, 27, ....

questions.text: Is i) 489 ii) 1592 a member of the sequence?

solution.a: 9-3=6, 15-9=6, 21-15=6, 27-21=6. The sequence is arithmetic with u_1=3 and d=6.

content.content: Solution for part d of Example 1.

solution.d_i: 489 is the 82nd term of the sequence
solution.d_ii: Since n must be an integer, 1592 is not a term of the sequence

content.content: Approximations using arithmetic sequences. Most real-world scenarios will not be exact. Random variation may give us a sequence where the difference between terms is similar but not the same. We can use an arithmetic sequence as an approximation.

content.content: Definition of geometric sequence.
definitions: A geometric sequence is a sequence in which each term can be obtained from the previous one by multiplying by the same non-zero number. We call this number the common ratio r.
content.note: A geometric sequence can also be referred to as a geometric progression.

content.content: Examples of geometric sequences and geometric mean.
examples: 2, 10, 50, 250, .... is a geometric sequence with common ratio 5
2, -10, 50, -250, .... is a geometric sequence with common ratio -5
content.note: The name 'geometric' is given because the middle term of any three consecutive terms is the geometric mean of the terms on either side.

content.content: The general term formula for geometric sequences.
content.note: The power of r is one less than the term number.
content.formula_box: For a geometric sequence with first term u_1 and common ratio r, the general term or nth term is u_n = u_1 r^{n-1}.

content.content: Consider the sequence 8, 4, 2, 1, 1/2, ....

questions.label: a
questions.text: Show that the sequence is geometric

questions.label: b
questions.text: Find the general term u_n

questions.label: c
questions.text: Hence find the 12th term as a fraction

content.content: k-1, 2k, and 21-k are consecutive terms of a geometric sequence. Find k.
content.solution: Check: If k = 7/5, the terms are: 2/5, 14/5, 98/5 (r = 7). If k = 3, the terms are: 2, 6, 18 (r = 3).

content.content: A geometric sequence has u_2 = -6 and u_5 = 162. Find its general term.
Find the first term of the sequence 6, 6sqrt(2), 12, 12sqrt(2), .... which exceeds 1400.
content.solution: Using a graphics calculator, the first term to exceed 1400 is u_{17} = 1536.
